ygData.subject: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
ygData.msgSnippet: Derek and Jeff, I would be happy to expand on my controversial remarks on interactive evolution being more natural than the usual kind of evolutionary

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: What's Natural About Interactive Evolution (Warning: LONG message)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=NkAmYk7Pt4CPXeXkAtv8ss1B4sj7J_C-fXmdbbrwBC7NA3P4MedT
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Derek and Jeff,

I would be happy to expand on my controversial remarks on =
interactive 
evolution being more "natural" than the usual kind of evolutio=
nary 
computation.  I've been thinking about this issue for a couple years =

so it will be good to get some of it down.  Please be warned this is 
a lo=
ng argument, but hopefully you will find it interesting enough to 
be worth=
 your time.

First, let me make sure the terms are straight.  I'm comparing=
 
interactive evolutionary computation (IEC), which means evolution 
with a=
 human (or "breeder") in the loop, to regular evolutionary 
computation, wh=
ich means evolution with respect to a given fitness 
function.  I have begu=
n to call the latter (at least to 
myself) "target-based evolution" (TBE) b=
ecause the fitness function 
in effect describes a target that a human desi=
gner is hoping to 
reach, so I will use that term here.  

Note that neithe=
r IEC nor TBE are really "natural" in the sense that 
natural evolution nei=
ther involved a sentient breeder overseeing the 
process nor did it involve=
 a predesignated target based on which each 
organism is always evaluated. =
 The question then is which one is more 
natural than the other, since neit=
her one is truly natural.

To get some perspective on this question, let's =
consider the simple 
task that Colin proposed:  Imagine that we set a parti=
cular desired 
image as a target and evaluate against that.  Could we then =
evolve a 
CPPN (or ANN if you prefer) that produces the desired image?

The=
 answer is surprising (we've tried it!).  It turns out to be very 
hard wit=
h anything but the simplest of images.  What you discover 
quickly is that =
the fitness function isn't rewarding the right 
things.  The images tends t=
o devolve into a gray cloud that minimizes 
error by choosing an intermedia=
te shade- not what you want at all.  

Yet the issue is deeper than that.  =
In fact, here is what is really 
interesting: If you take any image (except=
 the simplest ones) on 
Picbreeder- images that were evolved through IEC wi=
th NEAT- you will 
not be able to evolve to those same images through TBE w=
ith NEAT!  I 
challenge anyone to disprove me on this; I'd be very interest=
ed.

That is a remarkable observation: NEAT can't reproduce it's own 
resul=
ts!  The only conclusion is that the selection method is the 
culprit.  Tha=
t is, it has to do with how you decide what's good in 
any particular gener=
ation, which of course is different in IEC and 
TBE.

So let's look more cl=
osely at this issue:  How did we evolve images 
interactively that could no=
t be reached through regular TBE?  The 
answer is that humans have a differ=
ent way of rewarding intermediate 
results.  In particular, human breeders =
in IEC examine what is good 
*in the present* and make their decision based=
 on that whereas TBE 
compares what you have in the present to a long-term =
future goal.

Perhaps if you've used Picbreeder or IEC you may think that y=
ou were 
actually evolving to a target and thus that I am wrong.  But 
Picb=
reeder disproves this view.  As soon as *someone else* branches 
from your =
image, whatever "target" you may have had in mind (if any) 
is irrelevant. =
 They have their own ideas about what is good.  So it 
isn't possible that =
what the next person in the chain evolved was 
your original intent.

On th=
e other hand I may not need to go that far to make the point 
because if yo=
u're like me, you kind of discover what's cool as you 
go.  I may have a va=
gue idea in mind, but on the road to that idea I 
see that something cool I=
 hadn't thought of before pops up, so I go 
off in that direction instead. =
 What matters most is what's good in 
the present.

Now here is the connect=
ion to natural evolution:  Natural evolution 
is also completely unconcerne=
d with ultimate goals or targets.  It 
only concerns itself with whether th=
e present candidates are good in 
the present.  

I am going to argue that =
that is a major source of its power; it 
explains in part its prolific crea=
tivity and its astounding ability 
to elaborate indefinitely.  Yes, I am cl=
aiming that it can do all 
that because it *doesn't* have a target.

So the=
n what's so great about not having a target?  What's great is 
that you get=
 rewarded for doing what you *can* do.  And a good 
encoding can do a lot. =
 However, what's very difficult, even for a 
good encoding, is to do a comp=
letely arbitrary complex thing that is 
nowhere close to the current popula=
tion in the search space.

That is why I called TBE a liability:  It evalua=
tes the current 
candidates against something that ignores their current st=
rengths 
completely.  For example, imagine if the first bilateria (bilatera=
lly-
symmetric organisms) were evaluated for their humanity.  They would 
a=
ll fail miserably and they would all therefore be eliminated.  
Humanity wo=
uld never have evolved even though we in fact did evolve 
from the first bi=
lateria!  If TBE were in charge and humans were the 
goal, we wouldn't exis=
t right now.  

Try going back even farther.  Can you imagine evaluating si=
ngle 
celled organisms for their "human-ness?"  That would be silly.

Yet t=
hat is exactly what we are doing in most evolutionary 
experiments.  We do =
nothing to capture good intermediate ideas from 
which it would be possible=
 to build our ultimate objectives.  So we 
are hampered from getting anywhe=
re truly interesting.

Then you might ask, that's all well and good, but ho=
w in the world 
can we reward the intermediate serendipitous discoveries if=
 we don't 
know what they should be?  The  answer is: Respect the fact that=
 you 
don't know what they are.  Stop trying to *tell* evolution what it 
c=
an do and let it *show* you what it can do.  When it shows you 
something c=
ool, then keep that for later.  Keep everything with any 
promise for later=
.  You never know what might be a foundation for the 
next level up.

That'=
s exactly what natural evolution did and that's exactly what IEC 
(Picbreed=
er variety) does:  In nature what happened was that there 
were many ways o=
f doing a good job (at surviving) and there was room 
enough on Earth to su=
pport a lot of them at once.  Nobody "knew" 
which ones would form a good f=
oundation for something more complex 
(and many lineages didn't go anywhere=
), but because a lot of cool 
ideas were able to hang around, some of them =
happened to be good 
stepping stones to the next big thing.  The issue was =
where the DNA 
encoding could go next from where it is now.

Same with IEC =
in Picbreeder:  We don't know what we want to evolve 
collectively.  I thin=
k it's fair to say that we have no collective 
common goal at all.  We are =
all just trying different paths.  Some of 
us, when we see a cool path, tak=
e that path a bit farther and a bit 
farther still.  We keep all the interm=
ediate stages around forever 
and we therefore preserve all possible steppi=
ng stones.  Some happen 
to be genuinely good foundations for future progre=
ss, like those that 
produced the car, or the recent skull.  Yet who would =
have seen that 
coming?  If we had tried to evolve to them from the start, =
we'd be 
nowhere (we'd be in the usual TBE trap).

For this reason, what's =
going on in Picbreeder is really intriguing. 
It's the first artificial evo=
lutionary experiment that is really 
doing something like natural evolution=
!  We may have some amazing 
encodings out there, but we don't get to see i=
t because all we do is 
TBE, where we keep losing the intermediate foundati=
ons we would need 
to get to a new level.  Picbreeder is the first time tha=
t we let 
evolution show us what it can do instead of telling it what we wa=
nt 
it to do.  We are respecting the encoding just as nature respected 
DNA=
.

There are some important corollaries: First, TBE is not just about 
imag=
es.  In effect, all regular fitness functions have the same TBE 
liability.=
  Do you think you can evolve an amazing neural network 
with NEAT or with =
HyperNEAT?  Or something else?  Well, if you have a 
target behavior that y=
ou evaluate against, you are never going to 
know how amazing things could =
be.  This is a sobering realization.  
But it's just as true with behaviors=
 as it is with images.  (This 
insight suggests that evolving behaviors int=
eractively instead of 
through a fitness function is a really promising pat=
h)

One exception is competitive coevolution, wherein individuals 
actually=
 are evaluated against other individuals, so it's not really 
target-based.=
  In a sense individuals are recognized for being as 
good as they can be i=
n the present.  Of course, nature is a kind of 
coevolution.

Yet I don't w=
ant to pretend that competitive coevolution is the 
perfect pathway to comp=
lexity because the task may be defined in such 
a way that it might as well=
 be necessary to solve some gigantic 
problem to become good.  For example,=
 competitive coevolution on Go 
may not really end up rewarding individuals=
 for finding really basic 
regularities that are necessary to eventually ev=
olving a good Go 
player.

The key to natural evolution was that there were=
 a lot of easy ways 
to do well in the beginning.  So we got a diversity of=
 viable jumping 
off points.  That is also true on Picbreeder:  You can eas=
ily get a 
picture that's good enough to be worth showing others.  So it's =
got a 
very natural property: It proliferates jumping-off points too.

If y=
ou like, you can think of Picbreeder as an ecology where the 
environment i=
s just the preferences of its myriad users.  The 
environment in nature is =
just Earth and physics.  These are quite 
different environments, but their=
 effect on the dynamics of selection 
form an analogy.  So at that level, i=
t doesn't matter if a human is 
in the loop or not.  What humans like is ju=
st the environment.  And 
the nice things is, humans are very sensitive to =
regularity and 
organization at all levels: exactly what a good environment=
 should 
reward if we want to build up.

I don't know where Picbreeder will=
 go because part of it depends on 
how many users we get and how much they =
persevere.  So it may never 
produce great works of art; I'd be surprised i=
f it did.  Yet it has 
these intriguing ingredients that we have not had be=
fore, so it is a 
much more significant experiment than just a bunch of peo=
ple playing 
with an art toy.

Hopefully this endless message answers the q=
uestion with some extra 
food for thought to boot.  I know there are a lot =
of controversial 
ideas here and please forgive me for not reminding you as=
 I went that 
many such claims were merely speculation: I realize that they=
 are, 
but if I acknowledged that every time I speculated this near-novel 
=
would be twice as long!  You can be sure that I am not trying to 
present t=
hese ideas as settled facts by any means.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> Ken wrote:
> 
> > Of course the rea=
son it was possible is because humans are doing 
the
> > evaluation- which =
yields another lesson: The fitness function in 
most
> > evolutionary compu=
tation is a liability against getting to high-
level
> > complexity. There =
are deep reasons that human evaluation is 
actually
> > more analogous to w=
hat happened over natural evolution than any 
other
> > type of evaluation =
scheme we run on computers. We are often misled
> > into believing that int=
eractive evolution is less "natural" than
> > normal EC. Actually, the oppo=
site is true.
> 
> Like Jeff, I'd be interested in hearing you expand your =
thoughts on 
this.  I
> think the demonstration is no less impressive, but =
it seems to me 
that the
> distinction between natural and artificial selec=
tion is an important
> conceptual one.  Natural selection is based on the a=
ttributes of the
> environment, while artificial selection is the result of=
 attributes 
selected
> by an agent (akin to animal breeding or horticultur=
e).  In fact, in 
The
> Origin of Species, Darwin used many many examples o=
f rapid 
evolutionary
> change in domesticated species such as pigeons and =
dogs to bolster 
his
> argument for his theory.
> 
> Maybe you're taking is=
sue with the terms "natural" 
and "artificial", and
> maybe there are bette=
r ways to make the distinction ("agent-
directed" vs.
> "environment-direct=
ed", "conscious" vs. "unconscious" evolution...I 
don't
> know).  But while=
 I don't think artificial selection is any less 
effective
> or powerful, p=
robably moreso in some cases, I think it's useful to 
maintain
> that disti=
nction.
> 
> --Derek
>
